Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
6/11/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(d) Three references obtained from persons who are
unrelated to the staff person.
One of two new employee records reviewed showed that one of the employee's
three references was completed 5 days after the employee's 3/20/2024 date of hire.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar
days of its completion.
One of five special evaluations reviewed did not show documentation of the special
evaluation report being provided to the foster parent, as required by (a).
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all the following:
(b) Inform the foster parent, in writing, that the foster
parent has a right to have his or her written response
2

included as an attachment to the report required by
subrule (5) of this rule.
One of five special evaluations reviewed did not show documentation (b), as
required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services
worker that has children placed in the home.
One of five special evaluations reviewed did not show documentation (c), as
required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a
written adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family
signing an adoption application and prior to approving a
family for adoption.
One of five adoptive family records reviewed showed the family’s adoption
assessment was completed 18 days late per the family's 6/18/2023 adoption
application.

Quarterly progress reports, using the DHHS-614 are to

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE

R400.12419(1)(h) Initial service plans & R400.12420(1)(g) Updated service
plans:
The agency was apprised its child specific behavior management plan shall be
clearly indicated for each child, regardless of the age of the child.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.12418(3) Development of service plans:
The agency was advised noting the date and reporting period of the last service
plan onto its 30-day report may aid it in illustrating its review of that service plan
and the 30-day report’s connection to it.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one corrective action plan (CAP) during this period
under review. The CAP related to the agency Renewal Inspection completed on
6/9/2023 with a CAP approved on 6/28/2023. During inspection the agency
received 4 rule violations, 1 of which was a repeat violation this year. The
agency’s compliance around this repeat violation remained the same this year as
last year, in that the individual cases cited for the violation was 1 of 3.
In the agency’s 2022 Interim inspection, 12 violations were established, 1 of which
was a repeat violation this year. That violation is for the same repeat violation
cited last year; and the agency’s compliance around it as it relates to individual
cases cited was also the same 1 of 3.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted a Chief Administrator’s (CA) report dated 5/16/2024.
The assessment report indicated the agency believes it is in substantial
compliance with the rules and policies. In terms of key performance indicators
(KPI) the CA reported the agency had a couple of late dentals due to independent
living youth’s refusal and also foster parent /relative caregiver’s procrastination.
Additionally, the agency reported not being able to meet all parent-child contacts,
due to the parents consistently not showing up for the visit.
4

The CA indicated a system’s issue they have been dealing with is the long wait for
non-emergency dental appointments in Jackson for dentist who take Medicaid.
The agency continues to work around this issue.
The agency reported staffing has been stable and they have been able to increase
their client counts. They have also purchased an agency car which they anticipate
will assist them around matters of visitations and various other transportation
needs. As for last year’s CAP, the CA reported the CAP was beneficial in
highlighting areas of concern; and had a positive effect on helping supervisors and
managers track compliance and implement necessary new procedures.
Overall, notwithstanding the one repeat violation, they agency is in compliance
with their CAP.
Financial Overview
The agency submitted a 2024 annual financial budget, and end of the year
9/30/2023 independent financial audit. A review of these documents did not
reveal a major area of concern.
Staff Interviews
In addition to my discussion with the chief administrator, program manager and
foster care supervisor during the entrance conference, I interviewed a visitation
worker, foster care worker, adoption worker, and the adoption worker/licensing
supervisor. The staff reported positive remarks about the agency, the
administrators, and management of the agency. All reported feeling appreciated
and supported. They viewed the agency as a good place to work, and where there
is good communication, and solutions are offered and/or sought. Areas of growth
or improvements indicated was for more meaningful family team meetings; and
improving communication across programs related to shared/ and or transferring
cases, so as to ensure all are on the same page.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the facility was conducted and no area of concerns were
observed. The agency had adequate accommodations for it staff, and case
records were properly stored and secured.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There was one safety alert received this period, on 3/4/2024.
Safety Alert:
There is a mobile toy attached to one of the cribs that needs to be.
removed.
5

Resolution:
The relative caregiver removed the mobile toy from the crib. The agency provided a
photo showing the mobile toy was no longer attached to or over the crib.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
